metadata.title: Study of cracking mechanisms in multi-layered composite nano-structured coatings

sections.text:
The mechanisms of cracking in multi-layered composite nano-structured coatings deposited through the use of the technologies of filtered cathodic vacuum arc deposition (FCVAD) (coatings Zr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N, Cr-CrN-(TiCrAl)N, Zr-ZrN -(ZrNbTiAl)) and lateral rotating cathodes (coating Ti-TiAlN-TiAlN) are explored herein. The formed coatings are characterised by parameters such as hardness, adhesion strength to a substrate, elemental composition, microstructure, and the kinetics and mechanisms of wear. The microstructural studies have revealed the typical mechanisms of cracking and their influence on the kinetics of wear of coated carbide tools. The study also included extensive certification tests of cutting properties of tools equipped with cutting inserts of carbides with the coatings under study in thelongitudinalturningofsteelC45 (HB 200).The results of the studies have shown that all the coatings selected for study significantly increase the lifetime of carbide tools; the lifetimes were increased by up to 3–4 times in comparison with an uncoated tool and by1.5–2 times in comparison with a tool with a "reference" coating of TiN. The influence of ZrN on the cracking mechanisms of coatings and the kinetics of tool wear were also explored.
Keywords: wear-resistant coatings; wear; crack; fracture; tool life; PVD coatings.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The efficiency of the cutting tool is a function of the complex processes of contact interaction between the tool material and the material being machined, determined by various factors, including:
•thecrystal-chemical, thermal-physical, and mechanical properties of the material being
machined and the tool material.Depending on the conditions of their contact, for example dry cutting, cutting with CF, type of machining operation, etc., the level of thermomechanical loading on the cutting part of the tool may be influenced. •the geometrical dimensions of the cutting part of the tool, machining conditions and the
kinematics of motion of interacting tool and workpiece surfaces, etc.
In accordance with the above, during the cutting process, the contact areas of the coated toolare exposed to a combination of factors that trigger their wear and fracture. Such factors usually include:
•anabrasive effect between the material being machined andthe coated tool material; • adhesive and adhesive-fatigue processes at the boundaries of the contact between the
coated tool material and the material being machined, resulting in "ultimate fatigue" of local volumes the tool materialcoating, the formation of cross cracks from fatigue, delamination, and finally the removal of fractured fragments of coating and damaged volumes of tool material (substrate) with trailing chips; •macro- and micro-chips, as well as brittle fracture of local volumes of the tool
materialcoating, resulting from exposure to pulsed shock loads;
•fracture of macrovolumesof the tool material and the material being machined as a result
of the combined effect of alternating mechanical and thermal stresses;
•corrosion and oxidation processes;
•diffusion interaction between the tool material and the material being machined.
Depending on the cutting conditions, theabove factors may become dominant or, on the contrary, play asecondary role. Until recently, many of the factors with strong influences on the wear and failure of coated toolswere not well known. A brief analysis of the publications devoted to research of mechanisms of wear/ fatigue processes of cutting tools with complex composite coatings, formed with the use of the vacuum-arc technologies (arc-PVD), is presented.
Harryet al. [1] studied the mechanism of cracking in tungsten–carbon-basedmulti-layered coatings.The analysis of cracking probability showed a significant effect of the number and thickness of the elementary layers on the fracture resistance of the multilayered coatings. The best crack resistance was displayed by tools with afour-layer coating with a thickness of about 14 μm. The authors [1] have found out that the tools with thicker coatings demonstrated less intensive development of centres of wear on the front and flank faces of the toolsrelated to the high concentration of cracks, giving a lower tendencyof brittle fracture.
Moet al. [2] andBirol [3] presented studies of coatings based onCrN,
AlCrNandAlTiN.Impactweartestswereperformedtoinvestigatetheimpactresistanceofthecoatings. There was no visible crack formation for all three coatings during the impact tests. The AlCrN coating exhibited the best impact wear performance.Nohavaet al. [4]studied the properties of AlTiNAlCrN, AlCrONandα-(Al,Cr)2O3coatings. Wear track morphology and wear mechanisms were studied at ambienttemperatures, as well as at temperatures of 600°C an800°C by the method of pin-on-disktribologytests.The wear of the coatings at room temperature was governed mainly by an abrasive mechanism with potential contributions of micro-scale cohesive fractures. The main wear mechanisms at high temperature were oxidative attack accompanied by gradual material removal.
K.-D. Bouzakis et al. [5] studied the effect of the TiAlN derived coating fatigue behavior on the coated tools wear evolution in turning. The impact test was developed for establishing PVD coatings Woehler like diagrams at ambient and elevated temperatures.
Aihuaet al. [6] studied the properties of the coatingsTiN, TiAlN, AlTiN and CrAlN.The research of wear, carried out with a SiC ball counterpart, showed that the partial fracture could firstly occur from coating defects such as droplets. The wear mechanism of TiAlNwas a combinationof abrasive wear, oxidation, partial fracture, and micro-groove formation. TheAlTiN coating was worn by plowing and mechanical-dominated wear, and the damage was caused via a brittle failure mechanism. CrAlN coating presented the best properties of anti-spalling and antiadhesion.
Antonovet al. [7] focused on the properties of gradient and multilayer coatings (AlTiN-Si3N4 and also TiN, TiCN, TiAlN, AlTiN). Erosive, abrasive and impact wear tests were conducted.Their findings indicated that the initial coating failure may be accelerated by the presence of defects such as the local protuberances and droplets andconcentric cracks were widely spread throughout the impact site.
Henry et al. [8] studied the properties of six titanium aluminium nitrides Ti1 − xAlxN (0 ≤ x ≤ 1). Micro-indentation tests were conducted on the deposited coatings used to determine the fracture resistance. Ti-rich and Al-rich films present two different wear mechanisms related to their toughness values. Ti0.14Al0.86N and AlN exhibit strong wear of the surface, with the formation of wear debris trapped in the contact area, which is the result of a pronouncedfragile behaviour. For intermediate compositions, a complex wear behaviour due to the combination of wear mechanisms was observed for Ti-rich and Al-rich films.
To study the properties of coatings, a number of the papers used the method of nanoimpacttesting.In particular, in the paper prepared byBeakeet al. [9], this method was used to study the coatingsTi1−xAlxN (x= 0.5 and 0.67). The tests were carried out at temperatures of 25– 500°C. The variation in fracture resistance with temperature has been assessed by the probability of fracture within the duration of the test. The fracture probability on coatings decreasedas the temperature increased. Cutting tool lifetimeswerestudied under conditions of face milling of the structural AISI 1040 steel and thethe end milling of hardened 4340 steel (HRC 40) and TiAl6V4 alloy. Acorrelation was found between the results of the rapid nano-impact test and milling tests.
Skordaris et al. [10] studiedmultilayer TiAlN coatings with an Al/Ti ratio of 54/46.The coatingsconsistedof one, two or four layers. The obtained experimental (nano-impact test) and analytical (FEM model)results ascertained the fact that coatings with multilayer structures, due to their low brittleness, can withstand more effectively impact loads compared to monolayer ones.
Beakeet al. [11] studied wear performance of end mill tools with AlCrN monolayer and AlCrN– TiAlN bilayer coatings. The impact fatigue fracture resistance of the AlCrN monolayer coating was lower than AlTiN and AlCrN–TiAlN bilayers (by nano-impact test). The AlTiN coating that showed the best fracture fatigue resistance demonstratedthe shortest tool lifetime in the hard, dry end milling of H13 tool steel. The failure mechanisms observed on cutting tools werechipping from thermal fatigue and crater wear with build up edge formation.
In Ning et al. [12], a number of nano-multilayeredTiAlCrN/ MexN coatings (where Mex are transition metals such as Nb, Ta, Cr, W) and monolayer TiAlCrN coatingswere tested during dry, high-speed end milling of hardened AISI H13 (HRC 55–57). The TiAlCrN/NbNnanomultilayered coating showed the longest tool lifetime tested during end milling of hardened AISI H13 (HRC 55–57) die steel. The dominant wear mechanism for the worn coating zones was abrasion wear.
The studies presented by Fox-Rabinovichetal. [13] were focused on the properties of the coatings on the basis of systems TiAlCrN, TiAlCrN/TaN, TiAlCrN/CrN, TiAlCrN/WNandTiAlCrN/NbNnano-multilayeredcoatings. Coatings were subjected to mechanical(micro-indentation)analysis. Cutting tests have been performed under end milling conditions during machining of the hardened AISIH13 tool steel (HRC55–57).
In another study, Fox-Rabinovichet al. [14] studied the properties of AlTiN and TiAlCrN PVD coatings. In lab tests (nano-indentation, nano-impact testing), AlTiN coatings demonstrated high plasticity, twice as high impact fatigue fracture resistance and a significantly diminished probability of crack formation compared to TiAlCrN coating. Comparative tool lifetime tests during end milling of hardened tool steel H13 (HRC50–52) showed that TiAlCrN coatings outperformedAlTiN coatings by 27%. With theend milling of the TiAl6V4 alloy and Ni-based super-alloy the trend in tool lifetimewas opposite; AlTiN coatings superseded theTiAlCrN coatings by 12 and 70%, respectively. According to the authors [13], in many cases the hardness of coatings can be a marginal property where the majorproperties are the plasticity and impact fatigue fracture resistance; a surface with these characteristics is able to dissipate energy by means of plastic deformation and thus surface damage and wear rate are reduced.
The wear propagation of a TiAlN coating during the impact test at temperatures up to 400 °C was monitored by Erkens et al. [15] in terms of the coating fracture ratio (FR) versus the applied impact force. The profile of the coating FR under various operational temperatures captures the coating removal rate versus the impact force.
Beake et al. [16] appliedhigh temperature nano-mechanical testing to the study of PVD coatings (AlTiCrSiYN, AlTiCrN, AlTiN, AlCrN, among others), to help explain why certain coating compositions work well in some applications but not others. The hard-to-cut materials being machined during high speed machining tests.A recently developed multilayer coating, AlTiCrSiYN-AlTiCrN, with a combination of mechanical properties and microstructure can minimize crack formation and dissipate energy by crack deflection along interfaces.
A number of studies have investigated the influence of thickness and number of coating layers on cutting tool properties and durability of coatings at nano- and macro-impact tests.
G. Skordaris et al. [17] studied carbide inserts which were coated (by using TiAlN andTiCrAlN coatings)to the same overall coating thickness (from 4 to 8 µm) with various numbers of layers. The coating brittleness and fatigue were characterized by nano- and macro-impact tests respectively. The attained results revealed the coatings’ brittleness and fatigue endurance enhancement by increasing the coating's thickness and number of layers. This increase leads simultaneously to the coated tool life improvement (1.5-2 times larger in comparison to a TiN mono-layer coating).
The studies were also focused on different mechanical properties of such coatings as (Ti,Cr,Al,Si)N[18], (Al,Cr,Ta,Ti,Zr)N [19], (Al,Si,Ti)N[20], Ti-TiN-(TiCrAl)N [21,22], Zr(Zr,Cr)N-CrN and Ti-TiN-(Ti,Cr,Al)N [23]; Ti-(AlCr)N-(TiAl)N, Ti-(AlCr)N-(TiCrAl)N, Zr(AlCr)N-(ZrCrAl)N [24].
The review prepared by Bouzakiset al. [25]presents the detailed overview of the available methods to control basic properties of wear-resistant coatings, including control over crack resistance.
Bouzakis et al [5, 26] consider the influence of cutting speed on the prevailing tool wear factors, using simulation of finite elements method (FEM), as well as the results of cutting tests in turning. It was found out that at low cutting speeds, the key factor of coating failure is in coating static decohesion at low cutting speeds, owing to its overstressing. On the other hand, at higher cutting speeds tribomechanical abrasive phenomena are dominant. However, these factors do not result in loss of tool performance, which appears as a result of abrasive flank wear. The data of article [26] suggest that at cutting speed of vc = 250 m min -1 , assumed by this study, the prevailing wear mechanisms take place on the cutting edge roundness to the flank. The wear mechanisms on the tool rake at the applied cutting speed are associated with the coating fatigue and tribo-chemical reasons.
Following the summary of the results of the papers discussed in the review, it is possible to
note the following: - there is a relatively large number of papers,focused on the studies of various mechanisms of wear and failureof coatings, which use both traditional methods (study of hardness, modulus of elasticity, strength of diffusion and cohesive bonds, study of element and phase composition, tribological properties, wear resistance, etc.), and the relatively new techniques (nano-impact testing, study of basic mechanical properties of coatings at high temperatures, etc.); - only in some papers are the results of laboratory studies of various mechanical properties of the coatings confirmed by comparative lifetime tests of the tool during cutting. - various coating defects, in particular micro-droplets, formed in the process of deposition using vacuum arc technology (arc-PVD), decrease the performance properties of a coated tools and result in more intensive cracking in theircoating; - mechanisms of wear and failure of a coated tool under the conditions of real cutting and,in particular, mechanism of crack formation in the coatings, are less studied.
It should be noted that cracking of the coatings has a decisive influence on failure mechanism and performance of the cutting tool. Meanwhile, only a small number of papers are focused on the study of cracking in the coatings and their influence on performance of the tool. In particular, Tabakovet al. [27-29] discuss the cracking mechanisms with regard to mono-layered macro-size coatings on the basis of systems TiN, TiCN, (Ti,Zr)N, (Ti,Zr)CN.It was found that the coatings of complex composition of (Ti,Zr)N and (Ti,Zr)CNtypes better resisted intense cracking in the coating material. The authors attributed the obtained results to such properties of the complex composition coatings as high micro-hardness,level of compressive residual stresses,and microlamination of the structure, allowing more effective prevention of formation and development of cracks through the coating material.It was also noted that in the tool material-coatingswith (Ti,Zr)N or (Ti,Zr)CN, cross cracks occurred mainly in the tool material, while for the tool with coating TiN, cracks occurred in the coating.It was found out that the tendency ofcrack formation increasedwith anincrease in coating thickness from 3–7 μm.
Tabakovet al.also studied the multi-layered coatings with macro-size structure, in particular, on the basis of systems TiCN-(Ti,Zr)N-TiN, TiN-(Ti,Zr)N-TiN, TiCN-(Ti,Al)N-TiN, TiCN(Ti,Mo)N-TiN [30]. The conducted studies have revealed that the introduction of zirconium nitride in the coating composition sufficiently reducedthe tendency ofcracking.These data were obtained from the study of wear mechanisms of coated tool in milling of different materials under different conditions of cutting.The problems of cracking and brittle fracture of coatings TiTiN-(TiCrAl)N, Zr-(Zr,Cr)N-CrN and Ti-TiN-(Ti,Cr,Al)N; Ti-(AlCr)N-(TiAl)N, Ti-(AlCr)N(TiCrAl)N, Zr-(AlCr)N-(ZrCrAl)N were also discussed elsewhere [31-33].
When studying the wear mechanisms of a coated tool,it is important to developsimulation models that reduce the number of labourintensive experimental studies and provide clear understanding of the significant contribution of various factors to tool wear.The challenges of mathematical simulation of cracking in multi-layered coatings with the use of the axissymmetricalFiniteElementMethod (FEM) modelare discussed in paper prepared by Skordariset al.[9]. Papers by Xiang-FaWuet al.[34,35]are focused on the task to simulate cracking in monolayered coatings withintheframeworkoflinearelasticfracturemechanics (LEFM).M’Saoubi et al. [36] have investigated the nature of wear, including brittle fracture and cracking of PVD coated (TiN, TiSiN, TiAlN, and AlCrN) polycrystalline cubic boron nitride (PCBN). Coated cutting tools were compared to those of uncoated PCBN during single point turning of case hardened steel 16MnCr5.A notable tendency for TiN to exhibit plastic deformation was revealed, while TiSiN exhibited a more brittle behaviour evidenced by adhesive wear and micro-chipping. The high hardness and thermal stability of TiSiNgive this coating material remarkable wear resistance; however its more brittle behaviour makes it more prone to surface cracking, a phenomenon that is further amplified under the cyclic thermo- mechanical loading conditions occurring during hard turning.The increase in the wear resistance of TiAlN coatings is mainly attributed to its improved mechanical properties resulting from coherent isostructuralspinodal decomposition and hardening that occurs under the action of high applied cutting stress.The AlCrN coating, despite its superior oxidation resistance to the other coating material systems and high hardness, displays a lower crater and flank wearresistance. It has been speculated that this could be attributed to the formation of a hexagonal phase w-AlN at elevated temperatures thatresulted in the degradation of the mechanical properties of this coating.
Koseki et al. [37] examined the cutting performance of TiN-coated cutting tools deposited by arc ion plating according to the damage of the coating and determination of the required properties of the coatings. Defects (e.g., droplets, voids) in the coating were
found to be the starting point of damage. The breakdown region was enlarged by the work material being caught in the damaged portion of the coating.
Kumar and Curtin [38]focused on probabilistic mechanisms of development and inhibition of cracks in microstructures, in particular, at crackbridgingbyductileligaments, crackdeflectionbysecond-phaseparticles, micro-crackformation, andstressinducedphasetransformations. The same paper includeda review of the methods for simulation of crack development through the use of the method of Finite Element Method (FEM) incorporating cohesive elements at the continuum level,as well as discrete dislocation methodology at the mesoscopic level, and coupled atomistic/continuum methods that transitions atomic level information to the mesoscopic level.
In this context, the aim of this paper was to study the causes and mechanisms of cracking in
coatings that result in intense wear and fatigue failure of the tool material coating.

sections.heading: 2. Theory
sections.text:
The actual area of the surfaces of the material being machined and the tool material (including coated tool) in contact during the cutting process is less than their nominal contact area, which is predetermined by contact of vertical deviations of roughness. In the areas of actual contact, local specific pressure reaches a value at which plastic flow of metal occurs and thus the adhesion between the contacting materials dramatically increases. Theinitiation and failure of the adhesive bond bridging occur at high frequency of up to several thousand of failure per minute[37]. It is found out that the sizes of some adhesive spotsvary from several micrometres up to several hundredths of a millimetre, and the actual contact area can reach 10–60% of the nominal contact area, while on ametreof cutting path, each contact point is exposed to shear stresses. Thus, this process determines the alternating loading of contact areas on front and flank faces of the tool and adhesive-fatigue nature of their macro- and micro-fracture (wear).
Tool materialsareanisotropic and havevarious defects (inhomogeneity of structure, presence of pores, cracks, uneven distribution of residual stresses, inhomogeneity of chemical composition,etc.). Consequently, during the cutting process, along with the cut and separation of the material being machined, separation of fragments of the tool material particles also occurs. This separation is intensified as a result of the fatigue processes mentioned above and is defined as adhesive and adhesive-fatigue wear.
The most effective way to reduce these types of tool wear is to improve physical and mechanical properties of the tool material and, above all, its hardness by deposition of wearresistant coatings. Furthermore, coatings with less physical and chemical affinities with respect to the material being machined reduce the intensity of adhesion processes and significantly increases thewear of tool contact areas.
In explanation of wear by the theory of adhesive-fatigue process, the separation of fragments from harder tool metal occurs, like in adhesive wear, because of presence of cracks.Cracks are formed because of the influence of two key factors:
•repetitive mechanical stresses of a cyclical nature; • thermal stresses in the tool material characterized by different value depending on the
distance from the surface of the tool contact areas.
At periodic strain and compression of the upper layers of the tool material caused by mechanical or thermal influence, fatigue micro-cracks appear;further development then results in the growth
and coalescence of micro-cracks, which causesseparation of the fragment of the tool material and its subsequent failure.
The foregoing assumptions related to mechanisms of tool wear can serve as the basis for the
formation of requirements for coatings for cutting tools:
• coating for a cutting tool should be structured in such a way that they form residual
compressive stresses which may act as a barrier for crack growth;
•coatings should have a multi-layered structure so that their boundaries serve as
additional barriers to crack growth;
• the processes of formation of the coatings should contribute to formation of nano-scale
grains and thicknesses of coating sublayers, creating an optimum combination of high hardness and thermal resistance at sufficiently high fracture toughness.
According to existing theories, a crack starts growing with formation and movement of dislocations, resulting in plastic deformation of the material in front of the crack tip. Accordingly, the higher the level of plastic deformations in the material is the more energy is to be spent for crack motion. This level of plastic deformations is characterized by effectiveyieldstrength,σey. For plane stress conditions, according to the Tresca-SaintVenantcriterion [29, 38], taking into account the presence of plastic deformation at the crack tip, the maximum principal stressesand the effective yield stress are equal:σ1 = σey, whereσ1= maximum principal tension stress. 3.Materials and Methods

sections.heading: 3.1. Deposition method
sections.text:
For deposition of NMCC, a vacuum-arc VIT-2 unit was used, which was designed for the synthesis of coatings on substrates of various tool materials. The unit was equipped with an arc evaporator with filtration of vapour-ion flow, which in this study was named as filtered cathodic vacuum arc deposition (FCVAD) [18-21, 34], and were used for deposition of coatings on tool in order tosignificantly reducethe formation of the droplet phase during the formation of coating. The use of FCVAD process does not cause structural changes in carbide and provides:
• high adhesive strength of the coating in relation to the carbide substrate; • control of the level of the "healing" of energy impact on surface defects in carbide in the
form of micro-cracks and micro-pores and formation of favourable residual compressive stresses in the surface layers of the carbide material; •formation of the nano-scale structure of the deposited coating layers (grain size, sublayer
thickness) with high density due to the energy supplied to the deposited condensate and transformation of the kinetic energy of the bombarding ions into thermal energy in local surface volumes of carbide material at an extremely high rate of about 10 14 Ks -1 .
When choosing the composition of NMCC layers, forming the coating of three-layered architecture, the Hume-Rothery rule was used, which states that the difference in atomic dimensions in contacting compounds should not exceed 20% [46].The parameters used at each stage of the deposition process of NMCC are shown in Table 1.

An uncoated carbide tool and a carbide tool with "reference" coating TiN, deposited through the use of standard vacuum-arc technology of arc-PVD, were used as objects for comparative studies of tool life.

sections.heading: 3.2. Microstructural studies
sections.text:
For microstructural studies of samples of carbide with coatings, a raster electron microscope FEI Quanta 600 FEG was used. The studies of chemical composition were conducted with the use of the same raster electron microscope. To perform X-ray microanalysis, the study used characteristic X-ray emissions resulting from electron bombardment of a sample.
The hardness (HV) of coatings was determined by measuring the indentation at low loads according to the method of Oliver and Pharr [47], which was carried out on microindentometerMicro-Hardness Tester (CSM Instruments) at a fixed load of 300 mN. The penetration depth of the indenter was monitored so that it did not exceed 10 – 20% of the coating thickness to limit the influence of the substrate.
The adhesion characteristics were studied on a Nanovea scratch-tester, which represents a
diamond cone with apex angle of 120° and radius of top curvature of 100 µm. The tests were carried out with theload linearly increasing from 0.05 N to 40 N. Crack length was 5 mm. Each sample was subjected to threetrials.The obtained curves were used to determine two parameters:
the first critical load,LC1, at which first cracks appeared in coating, and the second critical load,LC2, which caused the total failure of coating.
3.3.Study of cutting properties
The studies of cutting properties of the tool made of different grades of carbide with developed NMCC was conducted on a lathe CU 500 MRD in longitudinal turning of steel C45 (HB 200).The study used cutters with mechanical fastening of inserts made of carbide (WC+15%TiC+6% Co) with square shape (SNUN ISO 1832:2012) and with the following
figures of the geometric parameters of the cutting part: γ = –8; α= 6; K = 45; λ = 0; R = 0.8 mm.The study was carried out at the following cutting modes: f = 0.2 mm/rev; аp = 1.0 mm; vc = 250 mmin -1 .
Flank wear-land values(VBc)were measured with toolmaker's microscope MBS-10 as the arithmetic mean of four to five tests and a value of VBc= 0.45-0.5 mm was taken as failure criteria. The study included statistical processing of tests of wear of cutting tools, sample mean value of
wear and sample mean square deviation of tool wear, which are random variables with different values in repeated experiments. Besides, during experiments, outlying results were excluded.
To exclude outlying results of the experiment, the Irwin's criterion was used. To do that, the value
of the Irwin's criterion K was defined, if the outlying result is the maximum value VBmax
K = (VBc - VBmax)/K
and of the doubts are provoked by the wear value with minimum value VBmin
K = (VBc – VBmin)/K
The calculated value K is compared to critical value K Α, defined theoretically for given
level of significance level Α and selection criterion n. If K<K Α, then deviation of questionable value VBc should be considered as valid.

sections.heading: 4.1. Determination of basic properties of NMCC under study
sections.text:
The study was focused on theNMCC containing nitrides of Ti, Al, Cr, Zr and Nb in its composition. For the detailed studies of various properties, NMCC were selected based on the following conditions: - if earlier studies showeda significant increase in cutting properties and reliability of the tool [21-24, 30-32]; - if the thermodynamic criterion ΔrG(Gibbs free energy change per mole of reaction) favoured the formation of the NMCC. In order to meet the research tasks, NMCC of various compositions were selected to meet the above conditions. Zr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N, Cr-CrN-(TiCrAl)N, Ti-TiN-(NbZrTiAl)N, Zr-ZrN(ZrNbTiAl)N, were deposited using the FCVAD technology and Ti-TiAlN-TiAlN was deposited using the technology LARC ®.The thicknesses of the coatings used in the studies were 2.44–11.7 μm, and a wide range of thicknesseswere selected to study the effect of coating thickness on the nature of cracking and on the basis of previous studies (in particular, [17]), indicating the improvement in cutting performance with increase in coating thickness. The basic properties of the NMCCunder study are presented in Table2. Curves obtained by mathematical processing of the experimental data are shown in Fig. 1.

It was found out that for longitudinal turning of steel under preset cutting conditions, the carbide tools with the NMCC under study had fairly close values of tool life of about 31–37 min, while the nature of wear of the carbide tools with the differentNMCCsunder study had significant differences.In particular, NMCC Zr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N provided the greatest increase in tool life, reaching 37 min at stable kinetics of wear on the stages of running-in, steady and catastrophic wear (see Fig.1). Almost the same stable kinetics of wear was showed by tools with NMCC Zr-ZrN–(NbZrTiAl)N, which had slightly shorter tool life of 35 min (see Fig. 1).The
tools with NMCC Ti-TiAlN-TiAlN also showed a long tool life of 36 min. Meanwhile, the tests showedless uniform kinetics of tool wear, which had the following specifics. It was shown that, if during 31 min of cutting (running-in and steady stages of wear) the tool wear rate was lower than for the tool with NMCCZr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)NandZr-ZrN-(NbZrTiAl)N, then after 31 min of cutting the wear of the tool with NMCCTi-TiAlN-TiAlNwas sharply intensified and turned into nearly catastrophic wear (see Fig.1).The tool with NMCCCr-CrN-(TiCrAl)Nhad the shortest tool life among the group of tools under study, for which 31 min of fairly uniform wear was followed by obvious intensification of wear of the tool.

sections.heading: 4.2. Study of mechanism of adhesive-fatigue wear of carbide tool with developed NMCC
sections.text:
During the research of the mechanism of adhesive-fatigue wear of the carbide tool with developed NMCC, special attention was paid to the studyof cracking. It was found out that the cracks under study usually had a width of several nanometers to 1 μm, so it is not possible to visually detect such cracks on the working surfaces of the tool by standard optical instruments.
Therefore, such micro-cracks were detected and studied on cross-cut sections with the use of a REM. Three main types of formed cracks were identified:cross cracks;cross cracks combined with longitudinal cracks (delamination), including transformation of cross cracks into longitudinal ones, resulting in stop of crack growth; and longitudinal cracks (delamination);
It is found out that the mechanism of formation and growth (branching) of cross cracks
usually includes3-4 basic stages (Fig. 2.):
 stage "a" is characterized by initiation of microcracks(see Fig. 2 a)caused bybending (usually alternating) mechanical and thermal stresses. An important role in initiation of a crack may be played by such concentrators of stresses as micro-drops (both embedded in the coating structure and superficial ones) (see Fig. 5a,c), surface coating defects (craters, rough spots, etc.), inhomogeneity of mechanical properties of the coating, etc.;
 stage "b" is characterized by the growth of cracks, which can be inhibited by various obstacles, including: "bridging" of particles of more ductile phase, embedded in brittle phase;phase transformations of thermal nature or occurring as a result of plastic deformation in the development of crack tip;change in the direction of crack formation during passage of grain boundary [38];
 On the “c” stage (there is implementation of cracks in the carbide substrate, as well as its "disclosure".
 stage "d" (typical only for a certain type of cracks) is characterized by penetration of particles into a crack of the material being machined (triggered by high temperatures and contact stressesresulting in thermoplastic deformation and yielding of the material), which has a "wedging" effect and stimulates further growth of the crack (see Fig. 6). The studied crack development stage may cause separation of a fragment of coating or coated substrate (Fig.5). The examples of different cross cracks at different stages of development are shown in Fig. 3 and 4. It is also important to note that in this case, despite the significant difference in thickness of NMCC Cr-CrN-TiCrAlN (2.78 μm) and NMCC Ti-TiAlN-TiAlN (11.7 μm), mechanism of cracking in those structures is quite similar. Through cross-cut cracks, including penetration of the material being machined, are clearly seen (Fig. 3 and 4). The study can also note fairly ranked "step" of formation of cracks in those systems.
Fig. 2.Stages of formation of a cross crack in multi-layered nano-structured coatings: a)initiation of a crack, b) crack growth throughout the thickness of the coating, c) "crack opening",d) penetration into the crack of a fragment of the material being machined, resulting in "wedging" and increasing the width of the crack by up to 1 μm.
Fig. 3.Example of formation of cross cracks in NMCCCr-CrN-TiCrAlN(with crack thickness of 20–150 nm).
Fig. 4.Example of formation of cross cracks in NMCCTi-TiAlN-TiAlN. A:through cross-cracks (stagesd and c).B:through cross crack filled with the embedded material being machined and penetrating into the substrate structure.
Fig. 5.A microdroplet embedded into the structure of NMCC Cr-CrN-TiCrAlN(a)and NMCCZrZrN–(NbZrTiAl)N(c) as a factor,causing formation of a crack; development of a cross crack in the coating TiN (b).
a b
Fig. 6. Examples of penetration of the material being machined into the crack, resulting in its further opening and penetration into the substrate structure (NMCC Ti-TiAlN-TiAlN).
Separation of a fragment of coated carbide substrate, occurring because of the final stageof the development of a cross crack is often accompanied by sufficient extensional chipping of the carbide substrate with locking in this area of a build-up of the material being machined(Fig. 7).Such cracks can be formed in hard, but not sufficientlyductile NMCC, making it prone to brittle fracture. The maximum number of the formed cross-cracks was observed inNMCCTiTiAlN-TiAlNand Cr-CrN-TiCrAlN.The nature of such cracks wasalmost identical to the one usually observed forcracking ofsolid single-layered coatings of simple composition and architecture (for example, for coating TiN (see Fig. 6b).

A typical example of the effect of adhesive-fatigue wear mechanism, which contributes to formation of cross-cut cracks and failure of coating, can be seen in Fig. 8. This Fig. shows that adhesive-fatigue wear causes formation of cross-cut (Crack A) and longitudinal (Crack B, along the border of adhesive underlayer Zr and intermediate layer ZrN) cracks, resulting in "tear-off" of coating fragment.
Fig. 8. Development of a cross-cut crack, which causes "tear off" of a fragment of NMCC ZrZrN–(NbZrTiAl)N.
The conducted studies show that NMCC Cr-CrN-TiCrAlN is characterized by an increased tendency to formation of adhesive bonds with the material being machined, and it results in formation of massive build-up on tool surface and is one of the reasons for deterioration of cutting properties as compared to other NMCC under study. In particular, Fig. 9 demonstrates massive build-up of the material being machined and a number of through cross-cut cracks, including those with penetration of the material being machined.

Fig. 11.Chipping of coating fragments as a consequence of the formation of longitudinal cracks (delamination) between two cross cracks on the example of NMCCZr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N.
Fig. 12.Transformation of cross cracks into longitudinal cracks (delamination) in NMCCZr-ZrN(ZrCrAl)N: partial transformation with continuous development of a cross crack (a) and complete transformation with stop of the growth of a cross crack (b,c).
Finally, longitudinal cracks (delaminations) (Fig. 13) may occur in connection with violation of adhesive and cohesive bonds between layers and sublayers of the coatingand in connection with the presence in the coating structure of different defects,resulting in the concentration of stresses (for example, microdroplets (Fig. 14), pores, failed "bridging" of adhesive bonds, etc.). The development of longitudinal cracks may result in initiation of quite extensive internal delaminations without reaching the surface of the coating (this option is more favourable for tool life) and in output the cracks of the coating surface (Fig. 15)with quite intensive subsequent damage of the coating and removal of the fragments of damagedNMCC by cut chips. sections.heading: 4.3. Cracking in NMCC on flank face of carbide tool
sections.text:
In contrast to the rake face of the tool, wherea sufficiently large variety of different mechanisms of cracking areobserved in NMCC, the flank face showed only formation of longitudinal cracks in NMCC(delamination) (Fig. 16a,b) or coalescence of cross and longitudinal cracks (Fig. 16c). Such abilityof the crack formation is stimulated by the presence of clear plastic deformations of the carbide substrate, resulting in relevant plastic deformation of NMCC. Cracking was observed on the flank faces of only two NMCC under study: Zr-ZrN(ZrNbTiAl)NandZr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N.
Fig. 16.Formation of cracks in NMCC on the flank face of the tool: NMCCZr-ZrN-(ZrNbTiAl)N (a); NMCCZr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N(b,c).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions
sections.text:
Mechanisms of cracking in nano-scalemulti-layeredcompositecoatings (NMCC) were
considered. The studies were focused onNMCCof Zr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N, Cr-CrN-(TiCrAl)N, and Zr-ZrN-(ZrNbTiAl)Ndeposited through FCVADtechnologyand Ti-TiAlN-TiAlNdeposited using theLARC ® technology. The thickness of the NMCCunder study reached 2.44–11.7 μm. An uncoated carbide tool and a carbide tool with a "reference" TiNcoating were selected as objects for comparison. Preliminary studies have shown that the NMCCsunder study are characterized by high adhesion to substrate and high hardness (34–38 GPa).The tests of cutting properties carried out at longitudinalturningofsteelC45 (HB 200) atthefollowingcuttingmodes: f = 0.2 mm/rev; аp = 1.0 mm; vc = 250 mmin -1 have shown that all NMCCunder study sufficiently improve tool life (by 3–4 times in comparison with uncoated tool, and by 1.5–2 times in comparison with the tool with the TiN"reference" coating).Meanwhile, the nature of wear of NMCC with harder and less ductile wear-resistant layers ((TiCrAl)N and (TiAl)N) was considerably different from the mechanism of wear of NMCCwith less hard and more ductile wear-resistant layers, which included zirconium nitrides (ZrCrAl)N and (ZrNbTiAl)N)compositions. The tools with harder and less ductile NMCC showed less steady kinetics of wear, characterized by sharp intensification of wear and failure in transition from "steady"to catastrophic wear,i.e., at the end of the tool life period. The revealed pattern was particularly clear for NMCCTi-TiAlN-TiAlN, with relatively high thickness (11.7 μm) and hardness(37 GPa). The microstructural studies carried out at cross-cut sections of carbide
a b c
samples with the NMCC under study with the use of a REM revealed the nuances and mechanisms of formation of different types of cracks in the various NMCCs studied.

metadata.abstractText: The mechanisms of cracking in multi-layered composite nano-structured coatings deposited through the use of the technologies of filtered cathodic vacuum arc deposition (FCVAD) (coatings Zr-ZrN-(ZrCrAl)N, Cr-CrN-(TiCrAl)N, Zr-ZrN -(ZrNbTiAl)) and lateral rotating cathodes (coating Ti-TiAlN-TiAlN) are explored herein. The formed coatings are characterised by parameters such as hardness, adhesion strength to a substrate, elemental composition, microstructure, and the kinetics and mechanisms of wear. The microstructural studies have revealed the typical mechanisms of cracking and their influence on the kinetics of wear of coated carbide tools. The study also included extensive certification tests of cutting properties of tools equipped with cutting inserts of carbides with the coatings under study in thelongitudinalturningofsteelC45 (HB 200).The results of the studies have shown that all the coatings selected for study significantly increase the lifetime of carbide tools; the lifetimes were increased by up to 3–4 times in comparison with an uncoated tool and by1.5–2 times in comparison with a tool with a "reference" coating of TiN. The influence of ZrN on the cracking mechanisms of coatings and the kinetics of tool wear were also explored.
